The Attica Prison Uprising: September 9-13, 1971

On September 9, 1971, the incarcerated men at Attica State Correctional Facility seized control of the prison. During the initial uprising, Corrections Officer William Quinn was fatally injured and several other prison staff are taken hostage. For four days, the men inside Attica negotiated with New York State authorities demanding redress of horrendous conditions within the prison.

New York Governor Nelson Rockefeller refuses requests from all parties to visit Attica, and on September 13, 1971, orders the prison to be forcibly retaken. After the prisoners refuse to release the hostages or to surrender, tear gas is dropped by helicopter and law enforcement unleashes a near-indiscriminate barrage of nearly 2,000 rounds of ammunition.

During the assault, 39 people are killed, including 29 prisoners and 10 hostages.

In 2010, the collection of evidence recovered by the New York State Police was transferred to the New York State Museum.

#ThrowbackThursday: Theodore Roosevelt at the New York State Museum
The NYSM occupied the State Education Building from 1912-1976 before moving into its current location in the Cultural Education Building. On December 29, 1916, former President Theodore Roosevelt hosted dedication ceremonies for the Museum's newly constructed building. "A museum of this character," he stated, "has more than one function to fulfill. It must present to the people as a whole in vivid and yet truthful form, knowledge of the natural objects of our countryside…in such a fashion as to be readily understood."

Women of Science: Non-Destructive Archaeological Surveys at Douw Site 1 with Susan Winchell-Sweeney & Kristin O’Connell

Archaeology is an important tool when investigating the lives of enslaved people living in the Hudson Valley. Discover how the archaeological remains of a house constructed by Volkert P. Douw, a prominent politician during the mid- to late- 1700s, provide insight into the individuals that may have occupied the site including people enslaved by Douw in the 18th century.

As part of a larger project to study the impact of slavery in the Hudson Valley, the New York State Museum, in collaboration with the Open Space Institute and Stockbridge-Munsee Mohican Tribal Preservation Office, undertook both a controlled surface artifact collection and a magnetic susceptibility (MS) survey at the Douw Site. MS is a non-invasive geophysical technique that is becoming increasing more popular for archaeological investigations in the United States.

Archaeologists excavated the Schoharie Creek III site and found a large house foundation and several cisterns dating to the late 19th and early 20th century. Toys used by children were recovered and include Anker building blocks, a small tea set, and several toy guns. The Anker building blocks (shown here) date to the late 19th century and were used by the children of the Alonzo Coon’s family. These blocks were created in Germany before being shipped to the U.S. for sale between 1880 and 1920.

#HistoryHumpday
In 1896, Christian F. Weeber opened his bicycle shop in Albany, NY. A decade later, he began selling Ford and other automobile models at his new location on Central Avenue in Albany. Weeber, ever the entrepreneur, decided to increase sales by supporting the first Annual Hill Climbing Contest sponsored by the Albany Automobile Club. Weeber won this trophy as first prize. Art comes in many shapes and sizes. In 2019, the NYSM acquired a large collection of artifacts from the Sherman Farm in Pittstown, NY. This 18th century farm had numerous delicate treasures, including these leaf carvings.

While the date and artist are unknown, these five carvings were likely made by a Sherman Farm family member. The art form originated out of China and is believed to have developed from Chinese paper cutting. They have increasingly gained popularity in the U.S. since the 1990s. Artists can spend months creating these carvings, carefully cutting out pieces and leaving the veins intact as they design an image within the leaf.

The Sherman Farm leaf carvings show depictions of nostalgic scenes from old fashioned lifestyles.
#HistoryHumpday #leafcarving

Do you know what happened this past Saturday, June 20, 2020? Ancient cultures all across the world marked this special occasion in their calendars with monuments and ceremonies. Today scientists call it an astronomical event but it is still widely celebrated throughout the world.

The Summer Solstice is the day of the year with the most sunlight in the Northern Hemisphere and the shortest amount of sunlight in the Southern Hemisphere. How does this happen? Since the earth is tilted on its axis in orbit, the sun appears over latitude line 23.5 degrees north (Tropic of Cancer) allowing the sun to reach its highest point in the sky.

For more information about the solstice, check out https://earthsky.org/tonight/solstice-brings-northernmost-sunset?utm_source=EarthSky+News&utm_campaign=0d9130a581-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2018_02_02_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_c643945d79-0d9130a581-394231957

On June 19, 1865, the news of emancipation finally reached the enslaved people in Texas – two and half years after President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863. Texas was the last Confederate state to announce the proclamation because it was remote and there were few Union troops to enforce the new law. African Americans across the Southern United States began celebrating June 19th, known as Juneteenth, in 1866.

New York State abolished slavery on July 4, 1827. Many black New Yorkers waited until July 5th to celebrate each year thinking it was ironic to celebrate independence day when their brothers and sisters were still in bondage elsewhere in the county. Emancipation celebrations in New York State were celebrated well into the mid-20th century.

For more resources and information on Juneteenth, visit the Office of State History: http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/research-collections/state-history/notes/juneteenth-resources-and-information

In the absence of gathering together for Pride Celebrations this year, our collections offer memories of Pride events of the past. This program from the 2012 Brooklyn Pride honors Storme DeLarverie (1920-2014), a bi-racial butch lesbian activist. From 1955 to 1969, DeLaverie worked as a drag king at the Jewel Box Review, the first racially integrated drag review in North America that often held performances in New York City. Active at the Stonewall Uprising, there are conflicting reports on whether or not DeLaverie threw the first punch. DeLaverie continued to fight against “ugliness” into her 80’s, patrolling the streets of Greenwich Village to protect the lesbian community.

One of our favorite engineering activities at Museum Club is the Egg Drop Challenge. Let your kids get creative while they design an egg-drop device.

MATERIALS: Collect materials from around the house like string, balloons, cotton balls, newspaper, plastic bags, straws, tape, etc. Most importantly, you’ll need at least one egg per design.

SCIENCE: Review the basic principles this experiment entails like gravity, drag, potential energy, kinetic energy, and air resistance. Think of examples: helicopter seeds, parachutes, protecting fragile materials during delivery. Plan out a design to slow down the process of falling and resist the force of gravity.

MATH: If you would like to practice some basic math and money skills you give the kids a budget and assign prices to the different products they can purchase to build the device using game-money.

REFLECT: What worked? What didn’t work? How would you have improved your design?

Please feel free to share any photos of your egg drop creations at #nysmuseum

Shaker Gift Drawings
The Shakers are considered the most significant communal religious society in American history. They fled religious persecution in England in 1774 and built communities in places like upstate New York. They were revolutionary in their attitudes towards equality—accepting people of all ethnic background and providing equal access to education and business opportunities for men and women alike. The Shakers excelled in farming, producing innovative goods, and decorative arts and design.

ACTIVITY- Gift Drawings used bright colors and featured elements from nature. Creating these drawings was an important outlet for practicing Shakers and became a valued part of American folk art. Draw something from nature that inspires you! Make sure to use bright colors.

LEARN MORE- Visit the online exhibit for The Shakers: America’s Quiet Revolutionaries here: https://exhibitions.nysm.nysed.gov/shakers/exhibition.html

#HistoryHumpday: Tobacco Trading Cards
From the nineteenth century into the early twentieth century, cigarettes were packaged with collectable trading cards. The cards commonly depicted famous athletes, stage actors, or other popular culture figures of the time. In 1888 W. Duke Sons & Co. Honest Long Cut Tobacco included cards of 25 “Presidential Possibilities” in their cigarette packs. The cards included President Grover Cleveland and the future President Benjamin Harrison who won the election of 1888. New York had five contenders in the election, including: Grover Cleveland, Chauncey M. Depew, David B. Hill, Roswell P. Flower, and William C. Whitney. #NYSMhistorycollection #presidential

Pictured are Chauncey M. Depew, Roswell P. Flower, and William C. Whitney

#HistoryHumpday
In honor of Earth Day, we look to the mid-19th century journal of farmer Diodate Brainard of Hubbardsville, NY. Brainard's family made their living as hops farmers. Relying on the the land, they grew large crops of hops and corn and maintained a small orchard for apples. They tapped maple trees for making sugar and syrup. The family also grew a variety of vegetables for their personal use.

Brainard's journal is now part of the NYSM History Collections. The page photographed here shows his entries from April 1 through June 6, 1848. On today's date, April 22, 1848, Diodate indicated that he set hop poles in the ground, plowed a field, and made syrup. (Hop poles were large posts that the hops would climb as they grew.)

Also pictured here is a ca. 1850 plow, made in Schenectady, that is similar to one that Diodate would have used. It would have been pulled by a horse or oxen to cut through the soil.
#NYSMhistorycollections #earthday #hops

Did you know that New York habitats attract hundreds of species of birds? Bring those birds to your window by having the kids make some simple bird feeders today!

Kids can make a pinecone bird feeder with a pinecone, peanut butter, birdseed, and some string to tie it onto a tree.

For our smaller bird watchers, practice those fine motor skills by having them string cheerios onto a pipe cleaner to make their bird feeder.

As our feathery friends start to visit you can use The Cornell Lab website https://www.allaboutbirds.org/ to help you identify the birds, listen to their sounds, and learn fun facts. See what birds are in your own back yard!

To learn more about the Ornithology collection at the New York State Museum, check out http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/research-collections/…/ornithology.

Fore! For many New Yorkers, April usually marks the beginning of the golf season. New York is home to the oldest golf club in the United States, Saint Andrew’s Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson. The first public golf course in the U.S. opened in the Bronx in 1895 in Van Cortlandt Park. Famous New York Golfers include Walter Hagen of Rochester, one of the first superstars of the game. He is the first American to win The British Open, the oldest and most prestigious golfing tournament in the world. Helen Hicks from Cedarhurst was a pioneer in professional women’s golf. She is the first woman to have her own line of golf clubs and was one of the original 13 founding members of the LPGA in 1950.
#HistoryHumpday #vintagegolf

#ScienceTuesday: Vertebrate Paleontology
While it is more fiction than fact that St. Patrick drove all of the snakes out of Ireland, it is undeniable that there are plenty of snakes to be found right here in New York State! In fact, many of the bones in the Vertebrate Paleontology Collection are from snakes. These bones give us a record of what species lived in particular areas of New York all the way back to the last Ice Age. Occasionally we find fossil bones of certain species of snakes that, due to changes in climate and habitat, no longer occupy the area today.

Photographed here are snake teeth and vertebrae dating approximately 4,000 years old that were recovered from Dutchess Quarry Caves in Orange County, NY.

In 1806, John Diefendorff and John S. Glenn, businessmen from Canajoharie, Montgomery County, posted a $50 reward for the return of their slave named Harry. Harry ran away on June 3, 1805. Letters in the State Museum’s collection tell us that Harry was thought to be in Boston in 1808 and in 1810 spotted in Rutland, Vermont, but his owners never found him.
�Underestimating Harry’s resolve to be free, Glenn wrote in September 1811, “Although I bought [Harry] under price I bought him at uncertainty at my own risk.”

From the NYSM History Collections:

Slave collar, brass, c.1806
This slave collar is inscribed, “J.S. Glenn/ GLENN/ Montgomery Co NY.” Slave collars were typically used to control slaves, especially those who resisted their masters. We have no historical proof that John Glenn required his slaves to wear such a collar.

Reward broadside, 1806

#ScienceTuesday: Native American Archaeology
Although Native Americans had used native copper to manufacture beads and tools for millennia, by the mid to late 1600s these sources were largely replaced by copper, brass, and iron obtained by Europeans. The timing of when these European metals began to circulate among Iroquoian people has been a topic of long-standing interest among archaeologists. Most archaeologists have accepted that the first evidence for European metals in the Mohawk River Valley of New York was no earlier than 1525-1550. In a recent analysis of over 60 radiocarbon dates from Iroquoian sites in the Mohawk Valley and elemental analysis of copper beads suggest that European metals were circulating to the Mohawk Valley as early as 1490-1500. Pictured here are beads manufactured of European cuprous metal from two sites in the Mohawk Valley. The article reporting the results of these analysis can be accessed for free at: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0226334
#NYSMresearch

A Confection of Fun from the NYSM Collections: All of these items are related to a chocolate and candy company founded in 1874 by New York native John S. Hurler. His first shop opened in New York City on Broadway and offered ice cream and candy. By 1881, he opened three additional locations. His shops were quick to gain notoriety because Huyler was the first to place a candy puller in the front window as an enticing ad for his product. Notably, between 1883 and 1885, Milton Hershey worked for Huyler before returning to Pennsylvania to start his own chocolate company.

Huyler's eventually moved its headquarters to Irving place and 18th street while expanding to 54 stores across the country. As with most candy companies, Huyler’s suffered two fires in 1889 and in 1917. After his retirement, Huyler’s sons ran the business for some time and, with additional help from investors, continued to operate several candy, ice cream shops, and luncheonettes. #HappyValentine'sDay #NYSMhistory #Huylers

The NYSM History Collections recently received a donation of multi-sheet braille music used by students of the Batavia School of the Blind. Music can be read by visually impaired musicians using a braille music code. Although it uses the same six-position braille cell as literary braille, braille music assigns a separate meaning to each braille symbol and has its own syntax and abbreviations. #HistoryHumpday #NYSMhistory #braillemusic

A free service offered by the National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped (NLS) provides a music collection to its patrons who have a visual, physical, or documented reading disability. They must first be a patron of the New York State Talking Book and Braille library http://www.nysl.nysed.gov/tbbl/ and then they work with NLS to get the music scores and instructional materials. More information about this service can be found at https://www.loc.gov/nls/about/services/music-instructional-materials-scores/

The iconic document, in the collections of the New York State Library since 1865, has been recently re-encased in a state-of-the-art, custom-designed encasement. The exhibition is dedicated in honor of the late Regent Judith Johnson.

Did you know that Albany didn’t “officially” become the capital of New York until 1971? During the 1971 legislative session Assemblyman Charles Henderson discovered that there was no statute officially declaring Albany as the capital city of New York State. Assemblyman Henderson introduced legislation to designate Albany as the capital officially. The bill was voted on March 3, 1971 passing with 134 votes in support to 3 votes in opposition. Those who voted against the bill cited the harsh winters as a reason to relocate the capital to another city in the state. Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller signed the bill into law on June 1, 1971.
#AlbanyNY

#ScienceTuesday: Invertebrate Paleontology
Although crinoids (also called sea lilies) may look like beautiful underwater flowers, they are actually animals with very plant-like features. Similar to the roots of a tree, crinoids have a holdfast that branches out and holds the animal firmly to the ocean floor. The “stem” is made up of tiny little circles with a hole in the center called columnals that look similar to Cheerios. These are stacked on top of each other and the living part of the animal runs through the holes. On top of the stem is the main body of the crinoid called a calyx. It is composed of solid plates attached together with a mouth and anus on the top. Long arms reach up from the top of the body and finger-like pinnules branch off from the arms. Most crinoids are sessile, which means that they are attached to the ground. They wave their long, hairy arms around and snag particles of food out of the water. Tube feet pass the food down the arm to the mouth on the top part of the body.
#NYSMresearch #crinoids

On this International Holocaust Remembrance Day, we pause to remember the 982 refugees who arrived at Fort Ontario in Oswego, New York. As millions perished, this small band, many survivors of Nazi Concentration Camps, would be the only escapees from the Holocaust to be allowed entrance to the United States during World War II.

“[T]he refugees sheltered at Oswego have demonstrated abundantly their gratitude for the haven that they found here. As artists, workers, entrepreneurs, they’ve made their own contributions to preserving and extending the freedom and opportunity that they found in America, making this a better country than the one they arrived. Whatever debt the refugees had to this country, they have repaid. And if they are proud of this state and what it gave to them, we are equally proud of them, of what they have given, what they’ve achieved, what they’ve meant to New York and to the Nation.”
--former New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo, August 1984

Even before the #ErieCanal, New Yorkers wanted “improvements in the internal navigation of this state” as Philip Schuyler wrote on behalf of the Inland Lock & Navigation Companies in 1796. He hoped to add canals to both the Mohawk & Upper Hudson Rivers.

Philip Schuyler ran the Northern and Western Inland Lock and Navigation Companies alongside Elkanah Watson. They began construction at Little Falls, New York in 1792 and continued various stages of construction along the Mohawk until 1803. In this letter, Schuyler asks for aid from a Mr. Weston who was then working for the Pennsylvania Canal Companies. Perhaps because the company faced financial troubles, Watson and Schuyler’s relationship eventually turned bitter, and the project petered out when Schuyler died in 1804. #NYSMhistory #ResearchUpdate

The New York State Museum recently acquired a journal that belonged to Diodate Brainard (1812-1885). Brainard was a hops farmer in Huddleville, in the Town of Hamilton, New York. The journal covers his daily life from 1846-1868. On this date in 1847, Diodate cut some “saw logs”, on the 20th he “drew” (pulled) them to the local sawmill, where they were cut into planks. Diodate picked them up on the 23rd. It appears that he was using the planks to build a floor in his stable.

Diodate could have used a log sleigh similar to this one from Cossayuna in Washington County.
The 19th century sleigh consists of two connected “bob” sleighs. The log or logs would be mounted on top of both bobs and pull by a horse(s) or ox(en).

Excerpts from January 1847:
Jan 15 - warm & rainy – cut a tree for saw logs – ground hard
Jan 16 - sawed small logs – growing cold
Jan 20 - drew saw logs to mill- very cold weather very clear
Jan 23 - finished drawing poles out of the swamp – drew home plank wood

#HistoryHumpday #NYSMhistorycollections

The New York State Museum is honored to announce that today it transferred ownership of Cornplanter’s pipe tomahawk to the Seneca Nation. The announcement took place at the Nation’s Onöhsagwe:de’ Cultural Center, where the pipe tomahawk has been on loan since March 2019. The pipe tomahawk will now be on permanent display at the Cultural Center, Seneca-Iroquois National Museum.

The 18th-century pipe tomahawk was gifted to Seneca leader Cornplanter by President George Washington at one of several meetings between United States and Iroquois Confederacy leaders in the years 1792 – 1794. The Cornplanter pipe tomahawk entered the New York State Museum’s collection in 1851 from Seneca diplomat Ely Parker. Sometime between 1947 and 1950 the object went missing from the Museum and for nearly 70 years was in the hands of private collectors. Thanks to the generosity of an anonymous donor, the pipe tomahawk was returned to the State Museum in June 2018. The pipe tomahawk was on display at the New York State Museum from July through December 2018.

Learn more: https://bit.ly/36OUYhf

Winter time is a great time for Ethnology collections staff to work on making storage mounts for objects in our collection. Each object has different needs for support. Pictured here are some of the museum quality supplies and tools needed to make mounts for unique objects so that they can be researched, admired, and preserved for generations to come. The steel pounded turtle shell in this picture is a new acquisition. Titled “Shedding Armor” by Margaret Jacobs (Mohawk), it is about to receive a lined storage box for when it’s not on display. #NYSMresearch

#ScienceTuesday: Cultural Resource Survey Program
Artifacts found in New York State are often evidence of the interaction between Native Americans and Europeans. This small “tinkling cone” recovered from the Pethick site in Schoharie County, New York, shows how Native Americans sometimes “reused” European artifacts for their own purpose. While it may have been previously part of a small brass kettle, the artifact's materials were refashioned by tapering and rolling it into a small cone that was then used to decorate clothing and other Native American items in the 1600’s. #NYSMresearch #pethicksite

In December, we often see wishes for “Peace on Earth” on greeting cards and decorations. The NYSM’s History Collections include numerous artifacts related to New Yorkers working and hoping for peace throughout the year.

1. “Best Wishes” etching by Carl M. Schultheiss
2. “Peace and Love” jewelry and fabric from the 1960s
3. Political buttons from the 1970s
4. “Statue of Liberty” created by a student at the Creative Women’s Collective, ca. 1980
5. “Stop Militarism” created by a high school student in a screen printing class at the Creative Women’s Collective, ca. 1980
6. "Stop the Cruise and Pershing II” printed by Jacqueline Skiles at the Creative Women’s Collective as part of the Seneca Women’s Encampment for a Future of Peace actions, 1983

#HistoryHumpday #NYSMhistorycollections #peaceonearth

#ThrowbackThursday: Behind the Scenes - Making Mastodons!
This snowbound mastodon momma and her young calf have been frozen in this Ice Age landscape at the NYSM since the pair were first placed on display over 33 years ago! Opened to the public in 1986, the exhibit took over two years to research, design, and install and required the expertise of a team of artists, designers, geologists, botanists, zoologists, and even a taxidermist! Photographs included here show how the ancient wintery landscape and masterfully crafted mastodons were created from start to finish.

Do you have any memorable NYSM moments? Share them with us here!

Lions and tigers and... holiday cards? Oh my!
Featuring a big top tent, gorillas, and even a clown dressed as Santa, these fabulously unique holiday cards belonged to renown Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus clown and Binghamton, NY, native, Pat Valdo. Valdo, who joined the circus in 1904, served as director of personnel from 1929 to 1969, after which he was designated the title of Director Emeritus. Born Patrick Francis Fitzgerald, he passed away in 1970 at the age of 89, having spent 65 years with Ringling.

The NYSM is lucky to have a couple of Valdo’s holiday cards in our History Collection. The 1941 card featured the famous gorilla Gargantua and his newly paired female gorilla Toto. The second card, undated, features a clown resembling Pat Valdo’s costume, dressed as Santa Claus.
